{{Infobox figure skater |name=Brandon Mroz |image= Brandon Mroz at 2009 World Championships.jpg |caption= Mroz at the [[2009 World Figure Skating Championships|2009 Worlds]] |country= [[United States]] |fullname = Brandon Mroz |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1990|12|22}} |birth_place= [[St. Louis, Missouri]] |residence= [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] |height= {{height|ft=5|in=10}} |coach= [[Tom Zakrajsek]]
Becky Calvin |formercoach= [[Doug Leigh]] |choreographer= [[Catarina Lindgren]]
[[Lori Nichol]] |formerchoreographer= [[Tom Dickson]]
[[Kurt Browning]] |skating club= [[Broadmoor Skating Club]] |currenttraininglocations = Colorado Springs, Colorado |formertraininglocations = |beganskating = 1994 |retired = |worldranking= '''23''' (''{{As of|2011|6|16}}'') |pbrankings = '''17''' (''[[2010â2011 figure skating season|2010â2011]]'')
'''23''' (''[[2009â2010 figure skating season|2009â2010]]'')
'''19''' (''[[2008â2009 figure skating season|2008â2009]]'') |combined total= 216.80 |combined date= [[2010 Cup of China]] |SP score= 76.10 |SP date= [[2009 World Figure Skating Championships|2009 Worlds]] |FS score= 146.96 |FS date= [[2010 Cup of China]] }} '''Brandon Mroz''' (born December 22, 1990) is an [[United States|American]] [[single skating|figure skater]]. He is the 2009 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. silver medalist]] and the 2006 & 2007 [[ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix Final silver medalist]]. He has the record of the first skater to complete a [[Quad (figure skating)|quadruple]] [[Lutz jump|lutz]] jump in a sanctioned competition. ==Personal life== Brandon Mroz was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]], one of four brothers. His mother and a brother suffered serious injuries in a car accident. Mroz's mother was at one time a [[synchronized skating|synchronized skater]], and his father a [[ice hockey|hockey player]]. Mroz aspires to become a dentist. He lives and trains in [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]]. In addition to singles skating, he has also trained as an [[ice dancer]] and tested in that discipline up to silver level in the [[U.S. Figure Skating]] testing structure. ==Career== ===Early career=== Mroz began skating at age 3 and a half. In the 2001â2002 season, Mroz competed on the Juvenile level, the lowest competitive level in the United States. He represented the St Louis Skating Club in competition. He won his regional competition,[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200102/ugl/juvboys.htm 2002 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Juvenile Boys] the Upper Great Lakes Regional Championship, to qualify at the Juvenile level for the 2002 U.S. Junior Championships, where he placed 6th in his qualifying group[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200102/jrnats/juvboys1c.htm 2002 U.S. Junior Figure Skating Championships Juvenile Boys Qualifying Group C] and went on to place 18th overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200102/jrnats/juvboys-free.htm 2002 U.S. Junior Figure Skating Championships Juvenile Boys Final Standings] In the 2002â2003 season, Mroz moved up to the Intermediate level. He won both the short program and the free skate at his regional competition to win the gold medal overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200203/reg-ugl/intmen-free.htm 2003 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Intermediate Men Final Standings] By this win he qualified to compete at the Intermediate level at the 2003 U.S. Junior Championships, where he placed second in his qualifying group,[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200203/jrnats/intmen-1c.htm 2003 U.S. Junior Figure Skating Championships Intermediate Men Qualifying Group C] 16th in the short program,[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200203/jrnats/intermen-short.htm 2003 U.S. Junior Figure Skating Championships Intermediate Men Short Program] and 7th in the free skate to place 11th overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200203/jrnats/intermen-free.htm 2003 U.S. Junior Figure Skating Championships Intermediate Men Free Skate and Final Results] In the 2003â2004 season, Mroz moved up to the Novice level. At the regional championship, the first qualifying competition for the [[United States Figure Skating Championships]], Mroz won the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200304/regionals-ugl/novmen-short.htm 2004 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and the free skate to win the gold medal overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200304/regionals-ugl/novmen-free.htm 2004 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Novice Men Free Skate And Final Results] This win qualified him for the 2004 Midwestern Sectional Championships, the second and final qualifying competition for the national championships. At Sectionals, Mroz placed fourth in the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200304/sectionals-mids/novmen-short.htm 2004 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and second in the free skate to win the silver medal overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=/content/events/200304/sectionals-mids/novmen-free.htm 2004 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Results] With this medal he qualified for the [[2004 United States Figure Skating Championships|2004 U.S. Championships]] at the Novice level. At Nationals, Mroz placed 7th in the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200304/uschamps/novice/novmen-short.asp 2004 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Men Short Program] and the free skate to place 7th overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200304/uschamps/novice/novmen-free.htm 2004 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Results] Following the event, Mroz competed at the 2004 [[Copenhagen Trophy]], where he won the novice men's competition after winning both segments of the competition[http://www.eiskunstlauf-ecke.de/archiv/2003-04/copenhagen_trophy_2004.shtml 2004 Copenhagen Trophy Results] In the 2004â2005 season, Mroz remained on the Novice level. At his regional championships, he placed second in the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200405/regionals-ugl/novmen-sp.htm 2005 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and in the free skate to win the silver medal overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200405/regionals-ugl/novmen-free.htm 2005 Upper Great Lakes Regional Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Standings] This medal qualified him for the Midwestern Sectional Championships where he placed 8th in the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200405/sectionals-mid/novmen-short.htm 2005 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and 5th in the free skate to place 6th overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200405/sectionals-mid/novmen-final.htm 2005 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Standings] Due to this placement, he did not qualify for the [[2005 United States Figure Skating Championships|2005 U.S. Championships]]. In the 2005â2006 season, Mroz remained on the Novice level for a third and final season. He had moved to [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] for his training, and represented the [[Broadmoor Skating Club]] there. A switch of club meant a change of region. Competing at the Southwestern Regional Championship, Mroz won the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/regionals-sw/novicemen-short.html 2006 Southwestern Regional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and the free skate to win the gold medal overall.[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/regionals-sw/novicemen-final.html 2006 Southwestern Regional Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Results] This win qualified him for the 2006 Midwestern Sectionals where Mroz competed for the first time under the [[ISU Judging System]]. He won the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/sectionals-mw/novicemen-short.html 2006 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Short Program] and placed second in the free skate to win the gold medal overall, ahead of [[Eliot Halverson]].[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/sectionals-mw/novicemen-free.html 2006 Midwestern Sectional Championships Novice Men Free Skate and Final Results] This win qualified him, again, for the [[2006 United States Figure Skating Championships|2006 U.S. Championships]]. At the 2006 U.S. Championships, Mroz won the short program by a point margin of 1.48.[http://stlouis2006.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=novice&ds=men&ev={249D6D13-7B5F-40F6-B8D0-71EC44908B45} 2006 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Men Short Program] He placed third in the free skate,[http://stlouis2006.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=novice&ds=men&ev={368E0D05-0B84-4B94-BF7E-3D27A49ADA4F} 2006 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Men Free Skate Results] 5.25 points behind the leader in that segment. Mroz won the silver medal overall, placing 2.26 points behind champion [[Eliot Halverson]] and 2.94 points ahead of bronze medalist [[Curran Oi]].[http://stlouis2006.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=novice&ds=men 2006 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Novice Men Result] In his free skate, Mroz landed all the triples except for the Axel, including a triple lutz-triple toe combination.[http://stlouis2006.usfigureskating.org/upload/general/news/novicemen-reports.pdf 2006 Nationals Protocol] ===Junior career=== Mroz was assigned to the [[2006 Triglav Trophy]]. Competing on the junior level for the first time in his career, Mroz won both the short[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/triglav/juniormen-short.htm 2006 Triglav Trophy Junior Men Short Program] and free programs to win the gold medal overall, winning the title by 25.84 points ahead of silver medalist [[Jamie Forsythe]].[http://www.usfigureskating.org/event_related_details.asp?ri=content/events/200506/triglav/juniormen-free.htm 2006 Triglav Trophy Junior Men Free Skate and Final Results] In the 2006â2007 season, Mroz moved up to the Junior level on the national level, and he debuted on the [[ISU Junior Grand Prix]] circuit. At his first Junior Grand Prix event, the [[2006-2007 ISU Junior Grand Prix|event]] in [[Mexico City, Mexico]], Mroz placed 11th in the short program and then won the free skate to take the silver medal overall, placing 7.53 points behind champion [[Kevin Reynolds (figure skater)|Kevin Reynolds]] and 0.16 points head of bronze medalist [[Daisuke Murakami (figure skater)|Daisuke Murakami]].[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgpmex2006/CAT001RS.HTM 2006â2007 ISU Junior Grand Prix Mexico Men Final Results] At Mroz's second event, the Junior Grand Prix event in [[Taipei City, Taiwan]], Mroz won the short program and placed second in the free skate to win the gold medal overall, placing 7.73 points ahead of silver medalist Reynolds.[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgptpe2006/CAT001RS.HTM 2006â2007 ISU Junior Grand Prix Taiwan Men Final Results] These two medals qualified Mroz for the [[2006â2007 ISU Junior Grand Prix|Junior Grand Prix Final]], to which he was the fourth-ranked qualifier overall.[http://www.isufs.org/events/jgp2006/jgpsmen.htm Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating 2006 / 2007 Junior Men Final Standings] By qualifying for the event, Mroz also earned a bye to the national championships and so did not need to compete at qualifying events. At the JGP Final, Mroz placed 5th in the short program and 2nd in the free skate. He won the silver medal overall, placing 20.07 points behind champion [[Stephen Carriere]] and 6.76 ahead of bronze medalist Reynolds.[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgpf0607/CAT001RS.HTM 2006â2007 ISU Junior Grand Prix Final Results] Mroz then competed at the [[2007 United States Figure Skating Championships|2007 U.S. Championships]]. Mroz placed second in the short program[http://spokane2007.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=junior&ds=men&ev={20B0075F-3180-40F4-AB32-2EDB650219C3} 2007 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Junior Men Short Program] and third in the free skate.[http://spokane2007.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=junior&ds=men&ev={C85B75A3-5B2C-4D2E-9CD7-D98289B33132} 2007 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Junior Men Free Skate] He won the silver medal overall, placing 9.23 points behind champion Eliot Halverson and 0.62 points ahead of bronze medalist [[Austin Kanallakan]][http://spokane2007.usfigureskating.org/Results.aspx?lv=junior&ds=men 2007 State Farm U.S. Figure Skating Championships Junior Men Results] This was the second consecutive year in which Halverson and Mroz had won gold and silver at the national championships. Mroz was subsequently placed on the team for the [[2007 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2007 World Junior Championships]] where he placed 7th in the short program and 2nd in the free skate to place 4th overall, finishing exactly two points behind bronze medalist [[Sergei Voronov]] and 0.08 points ahead of 5th place finisher Kevin Reynolds[http://www.isufs.org/results/wjc2007/CAT001RS.HTM 2007 World Junior Figure Skating Championships Results] In the 2007â2008 season, Mroz remained on the Junior level both nationally and internationally. He competed for the second consecutive season on the Junior Grand Prix. At his first event, the [[2007-2008 ISU Junior Grand Prix]] event in [[Vienna, Austria]], he placed fourth in the short program and won the free skate to win the gold medal overall, placing 1.69 points ahead of silver medalist [[Guan Jinlin]].[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgpaut2007/CAT001RS.HTM 2007â2008 ISU Junior Grand Prix Austria Result] At his second event in [[Chemnitz, Germany]], he again placed 4th in the short program and won the free skate to win the gold medal overall, this time with a 3.30 margin of victory over silver medalist [[Michal BÅezina]].[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgpger2007/CAT001RS.HTM 2007â2008 ISU Junior Grand Prix Germany] These two medals qualified Mroz for the [[2007â2008 ISU Junior Grand Prix|2007â2008 Junior Grand Prix Final]], for which he was the highest-ranked qualifier.[http://www.isufs.org/events/jgp2007/jgpsmen.htm Junior Grand Prix of Figure Skating 2007 / 2008 Junior Men Final Standings] At the JGP Final, Mroz placed second in both segments of the competition to win the silver medal overall, placing 15.86 points behind champion [[Adam Rippon]] and 5.30 points ahead of bronze medalist [[Armin Mahbanoozadeh]].[http://www.isufs.org/results/jgpf0708/CAT001RS.HTM 2007â2008 ISU Junior Grand Prix Final Result] This was the first time that the United States had swept the Junior Grand Prix Final men's podium. By qualifying for the JGP Final, Mroz received a bye to the [[2008 United States Figure Skating Championships|2008 U.S. Championships]]. At Nationals, Mroz competed for the second time on the junior level. He placed 3rd in the short program and 2nd in the free skate to win the silver medal overall, 10.13 points behind champion Rippon. He was subsequently placed on the team to the [[2008 World Junior Figure Skating Championships|2008 World Junior Championships]] where he placed 3rd in the short program after landing a [[axel jump|triple axel-triple toe loop combination]].{{PDFlink|[http://www.isufs.org/results/wjc2008/WJC08_JuniorMen_SP_Scores.pdf 2008 World Junior Championships Men's Short Program Protocol]}} He placed 5th in the free skate to place 4th overall, placing 3.40 points behind bronze medalist Guan Jinlin.[http://www.isufs.org/results/wjc2008/CAT001RS.HTM 2008 World Junior Championships Men Result] ===Senior career=== [[Image:Mroz 08TEB by Carmichael.jpg|thumb|right|Mroz during his free skate at the 2008 [[TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]]]] In the 2008â2009 season, Mroz moved up to the Senior level both nationally and internationally. He debuted on the [[2008-2009 Grand Prix of Figure Skating|Grand Prix of Figure Skating]] circuit. At his first event, the [[2008 Skate Canada International]], he placed 6th in the short program and 7th in the free skate to place 7th overall.[http://www.isufs.org/results/gpcan08/CAT001RS.HTM 2008 Skate Canada International Result] During his free skate, he was credited with a [[toe loop jump|quadruple toe loop jump]].{{PDFlink|[http://www.isufs.org/results/gpcan08/gpcan08_Men_FS_Scores.pdf 2008 Skate Canada International Men's Free Skate Protocol]}} Mroz went on to compete at the [[2008 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]], his second Grand Prix event. He placed 6th in the short program and 5th in the free skate to place 5th overall.[http://www.isufs.org/results/gpfra08/CAT001RS.HTM 2008 Trophee Eric Bompard Result] Due to the timing of his Grand Prix events, Mroz had a bye to the [[2009 United States Figure Skating Championships|2009 U.S. Championships]]. At Nationals, Mroz placed 4th in the short program[http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/34540/SEG021.HTML 2009 U.S. Figure Skating Championships Men's Short Program Results] after being credited with landing a triple axel as his required element axel jump and a [[lutz jump|triple lutz-triple toe loop combination]] as his combination jump.{{PDFlink|[http://www.usfigureskating.org/content/events/200809/uschamps/SeniorProtocols.pdf 2009 U.S. Championships Senior Protocol]}} He placed 2nd in the free skate,[http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/34540/SEG022.HTML 2009 U.S. Figure Skating Championships Men's Free Skate Results] in which he was credited with landing a quad [[Toe loop jump|toe loop]] and eight triples, including a triple lutz-triple toe loop combination. He won the silver medal overall, placing 12.19 points behind champion and training-mate [[Jeremy Abbott]] and 0.60 points ahead of [[Evan Lysacek]].[http://www.usfigureskating.org/leaderboard/results/34540/CAT010.HTML 2009 U.S. Figure Skating Championships Men's Final Results] Following the national championships, Mroz was assigned to the [[2009 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships|2009 Four Continents Championships]] and the [[2009 World Figure Skating Championships|2009 World Championships]]. At Four Continents, Mroz placed 5th in the short program[http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2009/SEG001.HTM ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships â Men Short Program Result Details] after landing a triple axel, a triple flip, and a triple lutz-triple toe combination.{{PDFlink|[http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2009/FC09_Men_SP_Scores.pdf 2009 Four Continents Championships Men Short Program JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER]}} In the free skate, Mroz placed 9th,[http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2009/SEG002.HTM ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships â Men â Free Skating Result Details] after landing a quadruple toe loop jump, but making errors on several other jumps, including his triple axel.{{PDFlink|[http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2009/FC09_Men_FS_Scores.pdf 2009 Four Continents Championships Men Free Skating JUDGES DETAILS PER SKATER]}} He placed 8th overall.[http://www.isuresults.com/results/fc2009/CAT001RS.HTM ISU Four Continents Figure Skating Championships â Men Result] In his debut at the senior World Championships, Mroz skated a strong short program to place 8th in that segment of the competition. He placed 13th in the free skate to finish 9th overall. His placement, combined with that of World Champion [[Evan Lysacek]], earned the United States the maximum three entries to the [[2010 Winter Olympics]]. Mroz won his first senior Grand Prix medal, silver, at [[2010 Cup of China]]. He followed it up with a bronze medal at [[2010 TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard]]. Competing with a dislocated shoulder, he placed 7th at the [[2011 United States Figure Skating Championships|2011 U.S. Championships]]. In August 2011, Mroz began working on other types of quads â the quad [[Loop jump|loop]], [[Flip jump|flip]], and [[Lutz jump|lutz]]. He landed a quad lutz successfully on September 16, 2011 in the short program at the 2011 Colorado Springs Invitational. The International Skating Union subsequently ratified the jump as the first successful quadruple lutz landed in a sanctioned competition. His assigned [[2011â12 ISU Grand Prix of Figure Skating|2011â12 Grand Prix]] events are [[2011 NHK Trophy]] and [[2011 Cup of Russia]]. Mroz became the first skater to land the quad lutz in an international competition on November 12 in the short program at NHK Trophy. == Coaches and choreographers == From 2001 through 2004, Mroz was coached by Shannon Nester and Debbie Howe. From 2002 through 2004, he was coached by [[Doug Leigh]] and Michelle Leigh in [[Barrie, Ontario]]. In 2005, he moved to [[Colorado Springs, Colorado]] and began being coached by [[Tom Zakrajsek]]. His choreographers have included [[Tom Dickson]], [[Lori Nichol]], and [[Jeffrey Buttle]]. == Programs == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Season ! Short program ! Free skating !
